item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows: Best Abilities In Yasuke's Bow Mastery Path
item.description:
Summary

  • Yasuke offers unique versatility in combat with his bow, specializing in ranged attacks for precision and impact.
  • Upgradeable abilities like Retreating Shot, Kyudo Master, and Poison Arrows make Yasuke deadly effective at range.
  • Larger Quiver, Clear Mind, and Marksman's Shot enhance Yasuke's bow skills, allowing for greater damage and utility.

With the release of Assassin’s Creed Shadows , players have been given two very distinct protagonists to play. In addition to Naoe, a ninja in the vein of traditional series assassins, there is Yasuke, the hulking tank of a samurai, who feels as appropriately unique in combat as he does in his adopted home of Japan.

This tank is not without versatility, however, as Yasuke has just as much variability in his tools, weapons, and moves as Naoe. One fun way to mix up Yasuke’s shoulder-tackling melees is with his bow, which may not be as flashy as the teppo but makes up for it with satisfying precision and impact. A few of his bow abilities stand out from the rest, and the very best make Yasuke deadly effective at range.

1 Retreating Shot

An Impressive Looking Flurry

  • Shoot 4 arrows at the closest enemy, dealing 10% ability damage each time while evading incoming attacks

Retreating Shot is one of Yasuke’s few active bow attacks and one of the most useful in melee combat. In addition to shooting four arrows in rapid succession, upgradable to six, Retreating Shot gives Yasuke a window of evasion during the whole flurry.

One of the best uses for Retreating Shot is first equipping Yasuke’s poison arrows and using it to begin an encounter with a tough daimyo or other boss. As four to six poison arrows sink into one enemy, the poisoned state is virtually a guarantee, dealing a lot of damage over time.

2 Kyudo Master

The Right Timing Makes Yasuke Lightning Fast

  • Release R2/RT when Bow flashes to trigger Kyudo Master, enabling a longer Posture Window and a faster Reload Time for 5 seconds

Right away, players will notice that Yasuke’s main drawback is his speed. The bow takes a while to charge into a stance shot, and though perks like Swift Hand help to speed the process up slightly, Kyudo Master allows Yasuke’s speed to be determined by the player.

By releasing a shot right as the bow flashes, Kyudo Master gives players five seconds of faster reloads and criminally easy posture shots. Even better, this can essentially be chained until arrows are spent, as long as the player’s reaction time is good enough.

3 Silent Arrows

Assassinate While Safely At Range

  • Unlock a new Arrow that has 100% Armor Piercing and removes 2 Health Segments with headshots on unsuspecting enemies

In general, Yasuke’s Silent Arrows are his most powerful ammo type. While Poison Arrows and Serrated Arrows may look flashier and contribute more in the long run, Silent Arrows are the best choice to assassinate a target at range instantly.

When fully upgraded, Silent Arrows combine 100% armor piercing with a massive eight health segments in damage. That makes one shot enough for a hidden rooftop Yasuke to eliminate even powerful ronin and samurai with one swift, silent shot.

4 Larger Quiver I-III

The More Poison Arrows, The Better

  • Increase maximum capacity for all arrows. +10 Arrow, +3 Special Arrow

Some of the best abilities in RPGs are also the most boring, and Larger Quiver is certainly both. As its name suggests, Larger Quiver increases the size of Yasuke’s quiver, allowing him to carry more arrows, which is important for two major reasons.

Firstly, Yasuke’s main quiver is sorely undersized when first unlocked, at a mere ten. The three levels of Large Quiver bring Yasuke’s quiver up to 40, enough for any castle siege. Secondly, Yasuke’s damage is at its best with special arrow types, and until upgraded, players are only allotted six of each. Upgrading brings the total to a much more usable 15.

5 Clear Mind

A Franchise Staple For A Reason

  • Time slows down around you for 10 seconds while aiming

By now, it’s expected for any Assassin’s Creed game to have a bow ability that slows time, and the same is true for many other RPGs that include archery. In the often frenetic chaos that is Assassin’s Creed combat, a window of relative calm to aim and fire off a shot can be an actual lifesaver.

Clear Mind works easily and for an especially long time, simply triggering upon activation and slowing time around Yasuke for ten seconds. Given Yasuke’s lack of speed normally, the feature works wonders in making it possible for players to switch out their melee weapons for a bow and finish an enemy before they cover that last bit of ground.

6 Level-Headed

Upgrade Clear Mind to Maximum Utility

  • While Clear Mind is active, Headshots increase the duration by 4 seconds

Level-Headed is actually an upgrade to another ability. It’s the third in a chain that begins with Clear Mind and goes through Effective Mindset, but it may be the most important of them all.

Level-Headed makes it so that successful headshots during Clear Mind extend the duration by four seconds each. Like other Assassin’s Creed games, headshots are relatively easy to pull off in Shadows , meaning that a player with Level-Headed can feasibly fight an entire ranged battle with time slowed just for them. Yasuke's playstyle feels anything but slow this way.

7 Marksman’s Shot

Make Every Shot Into Two

  • When hitting the target’s head with a Posture Shot, fire a second arrow by pressing R2/RT

Marksman’s Shot is a rare ability that is not technically an activated ability, but players will still have to trigger it for it to take effect. It works by giving players a window after any charged headshot, which most will be anyway, in which to fire off a rapid second arrow.

The real gift of Marksman’s Shot is that it does not need to be slotted and activated, but rather is always an option after unlocking. Especially early in the game and with powerful enemies, Yasuke’s headshots often leave the targets with one or two health bars remaining. With good timing, Marksman’s Shot fixes this problem quickly.

8 Marksman’s Stance

Chain Headshots As Needed

  • Marksman’s Shot is now a Posture Shot

The direct upgrade to Marksman’s Shot, Marksman’s Stance takes the ability to its logical and extremely powerful conclusion. The perk makes the bonus arrow fired with Marksman’s Shot a posture/charged shot itself, meaning that the bonus shot now doubles Yasuke’s damage.

Marksman’s Stance makes every arrow fired twice as strong, including twice as much poison or bleeding buildup. Further, it is a massive improvement in the utility of Yasuke’s regular shows for assassinations. With appropriately scaled gear, two posture shots in a row should fell any non-boss enemy instantly, or at least in two instants.

9 Poison Arrows

The Best For Damage Over Time

  • Unlock a new Arrow type that builds up the Poison affliction

For how hard Assassin’s Creed Shadows pushes Yasuke to be a dismembering, wall-smashing tank, abilities like Poison Arrows make Yasuke also a fun option for stealth and subterfuge. The only thing keeping the high-damage arrows from becoming many players' default is their low quiver size and refill availability, but that can be addressed.

Once players know the map, invest in the many Kakurega scattered around, and especially if they invest in Larger Quiver, Poison Arrows can easily become their default ammunition. At that point, Yasuke’s every bow ability can utilize the arrows and therefore increases the damage dealt exponentially throughout the entire playthrough.

10 Staggering Blast

A Powerful, Dazing Burst

  • Shoot a powerful arrow at the target, dealing 60% ability damage and pushing them back

Staggering Blast is likely to be the first ability many players opt for in Yasuke’s bow mastery path, and rightly so. When fully upgraded, the blast is arguably Yasuke’s most useful overall, and even in its most basic form, its pushback ability can be invaluable.

Done right, Staggering Blast can be used like Yasuke’s melee version of War Kick, sending enemies flying back. This could mean giving the samurai space or it could mean sending tough enemies sailing over cliffs, turning drawn-out battles into instant kills. Once upgraded, it automatically dazes the enemy as well, meaning even those that don’t fly off a ledge are all but dead already.

item.title: How Assassin’s Creed Shadows’ Depiction of Feudal Japan Compares to Ghost of Tsushima’s
item.description:
Summary

  • AC Shadows' architecture depicts a bustling, dense feudal Japan with complex design and influence from the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
  • AC Shadows offers a larger open world with changing seasons, contrasting Ghost of Tsushima in environmental design and scope.
  • AC Shadows successfully differentiates itself through unique architecture and a more dynamic environment, distancing itself from comparisons.

By now, anyone with an ear to the ground in the gaming space has heard the relentless comparisons being drawn between Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed Shadows and Sucker Punch's Ghost of Tsushima . To be fair, both games are set in feudal Japan, and Ghost of Tsushima left such a mark on the industry that any successor that is even remotely similar is subject to comparison. However, Assassin's Creed Shadows possesses a number of defining qualities that arguably set it apart from Ghost of Tsushima , should its loudest critics be willing to admit those differences are there.

With Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima being around three centuries apart from one another, there are bound to be plenty of differences in their architecture. Additionally, since both of these games come from different developers, their individual takes on the landscape and environments of feudal Japan are expected to contrast as well. As such, perhaps the many comparisons that have been made between Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima aren't as merited as they initially seemed to be and were instead largely based on the success and popularity of Sucker Punch's action-adventure game that preceded Ubisoft's latest.

Comparing AC Shadows' Feudal Japan to Ghost of Tsushima's

Comparing the Architecture of Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima

One of the most noticeable differences between Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima is in their architectural design. In Ghost of Tsushima , set during the late 13th century on Tsushima Island, architecture is more rural in its design, depicting Japanese villages that show the period's emphasis on simplicity and tradition. These villages are defined by wooden structures and thatched roofs, as well as the Shinto shrines that can be found in the countryside surrounding said villages. Additionally, Japanese architecture during this period utilized negative space to ensure its buildings remained harmonious with nature, and this includes its minimally-decorated interiors.

With Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima being around three centuries apart from one another, there are bound to be plenty of differences in their architecture.

Assassin's Creed Shadows , on the other hand, is set in the late 16th century during the Azuchi-Momoyama period, which significantly alters its architectural design. The Azuchi-Momoyama period was a time of significant architectural evolution, which involved increased urbanization and foreign interactions, so it already outperforms one of Ghost of Tsushima 's biggest flaws — its lifeless villages. Assassin's Creed Shadows features bustling towns, dense samurai districts, and even ports reflecting the Portuguese and Jesuit influences of the time. All in all, this means that Assassin's Creed Shadows features a busier, denser, and more complex depiction of feudal Japan than Ghost of Tsushima .

Comparing the Landscape and Environmental Design of Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima

The landscape and environments of feudal Japan wouldn't have changed as drastically as architecture over the three centuries separating Assassin's Creed Shadows and Ghost of Tsushima , but each game's developer still designed their worlds in specific ways. Ghost of Tsushima 's environments are more categorized by color and flora than anything else, whereas Assassin's Creed Shadows ' biomes occur through its real-time annual cycle. Ghost of Tsushima does feature a weather system and diverse vistas, but Assassin's Creed Shadows keeps its world feeling fresh by applying an ongoing shift in its appearance and mechanics.

Assassin's Creed Shadows ' open world is also significantly larger than Ghost of Tsushima 's, which allows it even more opportunity to incorporate environmental diversity.

Ultimately, while it's natural to compare Assassin's Creed Shadows to Ghost of Tsushima , such comparisons overlook the nuances separating these two unique depictions of feudal Japan. Assassin's Creed Shadows successfully steps out of Ghost of Tsushima 's shadow by offering players a busier, denser world driven by its changing seasons and complex architecture. Though AC Shadows will undoubtedly continue to succumb to these comparisons, its willingness to paint a fresh picture of feudal Japan nonetheless shows its commitment to individual identity.

item.title: Where to Find the Five Godai Shinobi in Assassin's Creed Shadows
item.description:
Assassin's Creed Shadows is practically overflowing with criminal organizations and enemy groups for Naoe and Yasuke to obliterate. All throughout the game, you'll be unlocking new circles in the Objectives menu, each filled with targets to locate. One such group, the Godai Shinobi, is acquired roughly halfway through the game. Given as a side mission by Katsuhime's father Shotei , this group of former students is actively working to undermine Naoe. As they are well hidden around the map, this guide will provide the location of each student, showing where to find all five Godai Shinobi in Assassin's Creed Shadows .

How to Start The Godai Shinobi Quest in AC Shadows

Complete Requiem for Rokkaku:

To unlock " The Godai Shinobi " side-quest and organization wheel, you'll first need to sit down and chat with Shotei and Katsuhime in "Requiem for Rokkaku." This quest acts as a sort of epilogue to the search for The Naginata , the Shinbakufu member in Omi . After fully completing The Naginata's questline, Shotei will be added to the " People of Omi " wheel in the objectives menu. "Requiem for Rokkaku" will be available immediately following.

You will not have to complete any tasks in this mission, as it is purely meant to set up Naoe's relationship with Katsuhime, which can lead to her joining the League as an ally, as well as one of AC Shadows' possible romantic relationships (Naoe & Katsuhime). During the chat, Shotei will give Yasuke a Legendary Bow, and will present the player with a list of former students to track down, initiating " The Godai Shinobi ."

Each of the five Godai Shinobi is named after an element – i.e. wind, water, fire...etc. You can start anywhere on the wheel, but make sure to check the recommended level, as they are not the same for each. If you are over the base recommended level, the Godai Shinobi will scale with you.

All Godai Shinobi Locations in Assassin's Creed Shadows

Void, Wind, Earth, Fire, Water:

Godai Shinobi Name

Location

Rewards

Map Image

Godai of Void

The Godai of Void is found in a cave at the northern end of Daikichijii Temple. This POI is located in the NE corner of the Goshiki Outlands province of Omi. You do not need to complete the small side quest to locate Void. Make sure to read the letters in the cave, as they provide exact locations for other Godai Shinobi.

Call of the Void Legendary Tanto, Damage to Tagged Enemy Legendary Engraving, 295 Mon

Godai of Wind

The Godai of Wind is found in a small camp near the Shimagahara Valley POI in Otogi Pass province, Iga . You should get the exact location provided if you read the documents in Void's cave.

Iron Dispute Epic Tanto, Adrenaline on Headshot Engraving, 275 Mon

Godai of Earth

The Godai of Earth is located in the Hijiyama province of Iga, just north of the region's name on the map. He will be chopping wood when you approach, so it is fairly easy to sneak up on him.

Rooted Thrust Epic Tanto, Damage with Bleed Engraving, 385 Mon

Godai of Fire

The Godai of Fire is located in a small camp past the burning temple at the top of Mount Hiei in Omi . Completing the small quest will lead you to his general location, but it is not required. Sakamoto is a good starting location, as Mount Hiei is directly northwest.

Cindersteel Epic Tanto, Armor Damage with Combo Ender Engraving, 375 Mon

Godai of Water

The Godail of Water is located directly east of the Godai of Fire, directly on the western shore of Lake Biwa. If you follow the coast up from Sakatmoto, you'll see a small cove that looks like half of a heart. The Godai of Water is found here, meditating on a rock.

Typhoon Tanto Epic Tanto, Buildup with Abilities Engraving, 260 Mon

The Godai Shinobi Final Rewards:

Aside from the individual rewards each Godai Shinobi drops, completing the quest will earn you the following:

  • Brutal Assassination – Assassination Damage II: The final tier of Yasuke's Brutal Assassination skill will be unlocked, but you'll still need to purchase it with Mastery Points.
  • Hidden Blade – Assassination Damage III : The final tier of Naoe's Hidden Blade skill will be unlocked, still requires Mastery Points.
  • 5500 XP

Additional Rewards From Shotei:

These rewards are given by Shotei upon returning to his location at the end of "The Godai Shinobi":

  • Soaring Tatsu Legendary Trinket

item.title: Wuthering Waves: Seaside Cendrelis Locations
item.description:
Seaside Cendrelis is a material that is native to the islands of Rinascita. To be more specific, it can only be found in a certain area that is hard to reach: Avinoleum. Wuthering Waves players can only unlock this area after completing the Main Chapter Quest: The Maiden, The Defier, The Death Crier. The quest is quite long, but it’s the only way players will be able to easily unlock all the Resonance Beacons in this floating fortress in the sky.

Currently, there are a total of 66 Seaside Cendrelis located all around the floating debris of the Inverted Avinoleum tower. The routes may seem simple, but some of them require Wuthering Waves players to switch gravity to find them. Here are the best routes and methods by which you can collect Seaside Cendrelis in Wuwa .

Seaside Cendrelis Locations In Wuthering Waves

Near Tower of Ascension

Although there is a lot for players to collect, most of the Seaside Cendrelis bloom in clusters. The first cluster can be found near the Tower of Ascension , and you will need to switch gravity to teleport to the Resonance Nexus in the area . Once you’re there, head to your left and fly a short distance toward the broken debris you see floating . There’ll be around 15-16 Seaside Cendrelis here for collection. Players should note that they need to be careful not to fall here and take their time in collecting.

Near Path of Bestowal

For this next bunch, you technically don’t need to switch gravity, as the floating island the materials are located on exists at both altitudes. However, because the Resonance Beacon does not, you'll need to switch gravity for the Resonance Beacon at the Path of Bestowal appears . Then, teleport there and head straight across. Keep going past the water and the pathways, as you will need to reach the edge of the building and fly across to the floating island. The collection process is very simple here as all the Seaside Cendrelis will be located within your eyesight. Just run around the island and pick up the flowers. Some of them will be on the outer walls of the ruin, whilst some will be on the inner walls.

Left From Tower Of Unity

This next bunch will be north of your previous location and closer to the Tower of Unity . You don’t need to change the gravity, so just teleport to the Tower of Unity Resonance Beacon, turn around slightly, cross the water, and fly in the direction of the tiny floating island. However, you need to be careful when you land since some enemies will spawn. Now just run around the area and collect all the Seaside Cendrelis. There should be around 11 to collect here.

Left From Holy Spire of Confluence

Your next area will be toward the left of the Holy Spire of Confluence , and you’ll need to teleport to the Path of Bestowal Resonance Beacon again. Then, turn around and fly across to the second floating island. Similar to the previous ones, just run around the area to grab the Seaside Cendrelis. They’re pretty easy to spot against the neutral concrete of the buildings. There are around 13 for you to collect here.

Hall of Swordsmanship: Ruins

The final route is to the Hall of Swordsmanship: Ruins , and it’s pretty easy to find. You don’t need to switch gravity for this one; just teleport to the Resonance Beacon, turn your camera right , and look towards the giant hole in the wall. Go through that, and you’ll see these massive statues. The remaining Seaside Cendrelis will be located along the walls and near the bottom of the statues. There are quite a few, so keep a lookout for them since they run along the walls above you as well.
